content: Engineered E. coli to produce caffeine. Design and testing of a novel biosynthetic pathway for the production of caffeine in E.coli. Custom-built a plasmid that co-opted endogenous guanine metabolism, tranformed it into E. coli, and tested for caffeine production.
title: CaffE.Coli

content: Analyzed unstructured medical records from patients with glioblastoma diagnoses to evaluate relevant, medication-based treatment patterns. Created novel line of therapy rules for regimen tracking and used time-to-next treatment estimators to determine which clinical approaches yield the most positive outcomes.
title: Data-Driven Analysis of Glioblastoma Treatment Patterns

content:
I designed, developed, and tested an SNN that simulates ischemic attacks within large, biologically plausible populations of excitatory and inhibitory neurons.

By exposing these networks to tasks of various complexities and sweeping neuroscience-inspired hyperparameters, I discovered that a family of similar coactivity matrices enables latent dynamics capable of leading to the same behavioral output.

The size and spread of this family is constrained by the E/I balance of the network, and suggests that robustness to ablation could stem from the existence of multiple solution spaces in a continuous activity manifold.
title: Population Activity in Balanced Spiking Neural Networks after Neuron Loss

content: Helped revive the space biology community @ Stanford by hosting speakers from across the bay area and by organizing Stanford’s first ever Space Biology Symposium! Check out the website we made below.
title: Space Biology @ Stanford

content:
A few days ago, a friend asked the following:

I’ve recently been wondering about the politics of unnatural technology. Like, what is the history of normalizing advancements that people find viscerally inhumane? Current technology in this bucket is pro-natal tech, BCI, cultivated meat, etc. Let me know if you have any thoughts or recommendations on what to read.

Two books come to mind that have helped me think about this. The first is Theodore Kaczynski‚Äôs Industrial Society and Its Future. Obviously, I disagree with his violent revolutionary approach and much of his ideological framing, but there are two points that I think he nails. First, society picks up technologies and runs with them almost automatically, like a snowflake sparking an avalanche. And second, that as technologies are integrated, the relationship between humans and society evolves in ways that often diminish individual freedom.

Kaczynski describes a human ‚Äúpower process‚Äù – having goals, exerting effort to achieve them, and exercising autonomy in how you do so. Fulfilling the power process is a key part of our happiness. In his view, industrial society undercuts this process: our basic needs are met too easily, so we fill the gap with surrogate activities that mimic the feeling of striving but leave us fundamentally unfulfilled. Technologies, once introduced, spread like wildfire. They’re absorbed rapidly because many scientists, engineers, and institutions are incentivized to integrate them into society. He uses the car as an example: automobiles initially expanded mobility, but over time, they also reduced freedom by locking us into licensing regimes, regulatory systems, and built environments that make life almost impossible without them. For him, the paradox is that the more technology we adopt, the less true freedom we retain.

What‚Äôs most compelling to me is how he frames this process as self-propagating: systems adjust humans to fit their needs, not the other way around. Think of medicating schoolchildren so they can conform to the classroom system rather than reshaping the system to fit different learning styles. Each step is justified as a rational fix to a social problem, but the cumulative effect is a tightening system of control. He predicts that genetic engineering and other interventions will only deepen this trend, altering humanity itself to better serve the needs of technological society.

The second book is Aldous Huxley‚Äôs Brave New World, which describes a post-industrial society where ‚Äúunnatural‚Äù technologies are normalized, forming the foundation of social stability. Unlike Orwell‚Äôs 1984, where order is enforced through coercion and surveillance, Huxley imagines a world where contentment is engineered: people are biologically and socially conditioned to embrace their roles, and resistance feels impossible and, more importantly, unpleasant. In many ways, it‚Äôs a society optimized for happiness, but one in which happiness has been redefined into something shallow and managed. The book ends with the main character rejecting the entire system in favor of a simpler life.

For me, the heart of the issue is that unnatural technology is seductive. We crave new knowledge and new ways to modulate our existence. The advances you mentioned‚Äîpro-natal tech, BCIs, and cultivated meat are incredibly exciting, and they‚Äôre also the tools that could enable humanity to organize at the scale needed to solve climate change. But there‚Äôs a thin line between being augmented and being supplanted. As much as I love technology, I find the Brave New World scenario deeply unsettling. There has to be a middle ground where technology uplifts us rather than reduces us to managed, dependent beings.

Clarifying that line, making sure our relationship with technology is cooperative rather than one of quiet domination, seems like the key to keeping it human. Decentralized technologies (which can be built/harnessed by small groups of people) are one such axis. Think language, engineered yeast that produces pharmaceuticals when given simple sugars, the radio, blockchain (sans the internet), 3D printers, at-home methane generators, etc.

I think that progress in the types of technology you’re describing is inevitable, and net good; in my ideal world, for centralized technologies, the government should work to ensure that the scope of the advances remains in the public good by regulating how the technology evolves. This necessitates a technician class in government who can see outside their own hubris. Good in theory, hard to implement in practice.

Related: Technology without industry, George Hotz
description: Kaczynski, Brave New World, and Technology for the Public Good
title: Advancing Viscerally Unhuman Technology

content:
About a year and a half ago, skiing through the Colorado backcountry, I tripped on a stray branch and suffered one of the most excruciating injuries of my life: an anterior shoulder dislocation. Ski patrol tried, and failed, to reduce it on the slopes. After an hour of snowmobiles, vans, and gritted teeth, an ER doctor finally slid my shoulder back in place.

Around the same time, my cousin, same age, height, build, and activity level, dislocated his shoulder while playing basketball in Greece. Like me, he ended up in the ER. Like me, he was told he needed surgery.

Dislocations happen when the ball of the shoulder joint pops out of its shallow socket. With every dislocation, the risk of recurrent dislocations increases exponentially, especially in younger, active people. When we visited the hospital, we were told roughly the same thing: you’re at a high risk for re-injury; surgery would restore stability and protect your range of motion.

I had my surgery in Ohio at one of the top orthopedic centers in the U.S. My cousin had his in Athens at one of Greece‚Äôs best clinics. We both received wonderful care, had similar physical therapy regimens, and got back to the sports we loved within a few months.¬†

A year later, I was climbing when my shoulder dislocated again, same excruciating pain, same ER routine. This time, though, frustration outweighed pain: how had my ‚Äúfixed‚Äù shoulder failed, while my cousin‚Äôs was holding strong?

Digging deeper, even though our dislocations were physically similar, our surgeries were not. I received a Bankart Repair, a minimally invasive method where surgeons reattach the torn cartilage to the shoulder socket. My cousin received a Latarjet Procedure, a much more invasive technique that reinforces the socket with a bone graft from the shoulder blade, creating a physical and muscular barrier against future dislocations. The Latarjet is more durable for active people with a high risk of recurrence, but has a ten times higher complication rate. In the U.S., the default standard of care is the Bankart repair, despite studies showing it‚Äôs 54% more likely to lead to long-term instability in high-risk patients.

When I asked my surgeons why they hadn‚Äôt done the Latarjet in the first place, their answers were vague: it‚Äôs more invasive, more complicated, and not typically a first-line treatment. It seemed like they were saying, implicitly, ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs wait until the Bankart fails, and then we‚Äôll escalate.‚Äù But why wasn‚Äôt the better (if riskier) surgery done first, when it could‚Äôve saved me from going through all this twice?

Why is our medical system so afraid of doing the right thing the first time?

My experience isn‚Äôt just a personal frustration but a symptom of a deeper flaw in U.S. healthcare. Defensive medicine occurs when doctors make clinical decisions not only based on medical need, but also on legal risk. In my case, the Latarjet might have offered better long-term outcomes but came with more potential complications, and therefore, more legal liability. So, the safer option, from a malpractice perspective, prevailed.

The concept of defensive medicine first gained traction in the U.S. in the late 1960s, when malpractice lawsuits began to spike. Today, it’s pervasive. Nearly one in three U.S. doctors has been sued during their career. Such legal exposure actively shapes how doctors practice. ‚ÄúPositive‚Äù defensive medicine leads to excessive, costly tests; ‚Äúnegative‚Äù defensive medicine, like in my case, means avoiding higher-risk treatments, even when they‚Äôre more appropriate.

By contrast, my cousin‚Äôs doctor had no such pressure. Many European countries operate under no-fault medical systems, where physicians aren‚Äôt personally liable for adverse outcomes and patients can receive compensation without having to prove negligence. In Sweden and New Zealand, if you‚Äôre injured, you‚Äôre paid by the state. Doctors aren‚Äôt dragged to court, and clinical decisions are made with medicine, not lawsuits, in mind. Greece, while still operating under a fault-based system like the U.S., doesn‚Äôt have the same volume of malpractice litigation or the same culture of legal fear. Although patients can, and often do, pursue claims through both civil and criminal courts, the process is slow and unpredictable. The result is that doctors still feel some pressure, but not the same ever-present liability paranoia that drives American defensive medicine.

The difference isn‚Äôt just theoretical. Researchers studying U.S. military hospitals, where active-duty patients cannot sue their doctors, found that physicians spent 5% less on inpatient care without any decline in patient outcomes. When veterans were shifted from lawsuit-immune military providers to civilian ones, costs rose, but health outcomes didn‚Äôt improve. According to another estimate, defensive medicine accounts for 5‚Äì9% of all U.S. healthcare spending. In 2021, with healthcare expenditures nearing $4 trillion, even the low end of that estimate translates to hundreds of billions of dollars annually in unnecessary costs, including tests, procedures, and repeat hospitalizations that don‚Äôt improve patients’ health.

By compensating more patients directly and bypassing the tort system, a no-fault model could cover three times more victims while costing the same as current malpractice premiums. Yet such reforms would face steep resistance, from the trial bar, entrenched bureaucracy, and the inertia of a system more afraid of risk than failure.

As with so much in American governance, we‚Äôve overcorrected for liability and undercorrected for trust. Doctors work in constant fear of punishment for doing the wrong thing, even though they‚Äôre the ones who are supposed to be in the wheelhouse.¬†

I didn‚Äôt need a second surgery. I needed a system that let my doctors act like my cousins did: boldly, with clarity, and without fear of being punished for doing their job.
description: My experience with shoulder surgery and defensive health systems
title: A Tale of Two Shoulders

content: Built a working computer system on a RPi from the ground up: starting in assembly and working from bare-metal. With no operating system safety net and extremely minimal use of libraries, I implemented the following in C: GPIO interface, memory allocator, string formatting and graphics libraries, shell, PS2 keyboard and mouse drivers.
title: Raspberry Pi Computer System

content:
Projects

This directory contains project markdown files for your portfolio. Each project should be a single markdown file with front matter and content.

Creating a New Project

  1. Create a new markdown file in this directory with a descriptive filename (e.g., my-awesome-project.md)
  2. Use the following front matter template:
---
title: "Project Title"
date: 2023-01-01
draft: false
summary: "A brief description of the project"
cover: "project-image.jpg"  # Place images in /static/images/projects/
project_tags: ["tag1", "tag2"]  # Add relevant tags

# Optional links (uncomment and fill as needed)
# repo: "https://github.com/username/repo"
# website: "https://example.com"
# demo: "https://demo.example.com"
# pdf: "document.pdf"  # Place PDFs in /static/files/
# paper: "https://arxiv.org/abs/..."

# Or use the flexible links array for custom buttons:
# links:
#   - label: "Documentation"
#     url: "https://docs.example.com"
#     icon: "fas fa-book"
#   - label: "Video"
#     url: "https://youtube.com/..."
#     icon: "fas fa-video"
---

## Project Overview

Write your project content here using Markdown.

Adding Images

  1. Place all project images in /static/images/projects/
  2. Reference them in your markdown using the filename only (e.g., cover: "project-screenshot.jpg")
  3. In your markdown content, use standard Markdown image syntax: 
    ![Alt text](project-screenshot.jpg)

Tags

Use the project_tags front matter to add tags to your project. These will be used for filtering on the projects page.

Example Project

Here’s a complete example of a project markdown file:

---
title: "My Awesome Project"
date: 2023-06-15
draft: false
summary: "A web application built with React and Node.js"
cover: "awesome-project-cover.jpg"
project_tags: ["Web Development", "React", "Node.js"]
repo: "https://github.com/username/awesome-project"
demo: "https://awesome-project.example.com"
---

## Project Overview

This is my awesome project that does amazing things.

## Features

- Feature 1
- Feature 2
- Feature 3

## Technologies Used

- React
- Node.js
- MongoDB

## Screenshot

![Screenshot](awesome-project-screenshot.jpg)
